revision.comment: /* Post-war career */http→https for [[Google Books]] and [[Google News]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox astronaut | name = Iven C. Kincheloe Jr. | type = [[United States Air Force|USAF]] [[Astronaut]] | image = Iven Kincheloe photo portrait head and shoulders.jpg | nationality = [[United States|American]] | status = Deceased | birth_name = Iven Carl Kincheloe Jr. | birth_date = {{Birth date|1928|7|2}} | death_date = {{Death date and age|1958|7|26|1928|7|2|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Detroit, Michigan]], U.S. | death_place = [[Edwards Air Force Base]], [[California]], U.S. | occupation = [[Test pilot]] | alma_mater = [[Purdue University]], B.S. 1949 | rank = [[Captain (United States)|Captain]], [[United States Air Force|USAF]] | selection = [[List of astronauts by selection#1957|1957 MISS Group]] | space_time = | insignia = | awards = [[File:Silver Star ribbon-3d.svg|30px]] [[Silver Star]]
[[File:Dfc-usa.jpg|20px|link=Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)]] [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] }} '''Iven Carl "Kinch" Kincheloe Jr.''''''Iven Carl Kincheloe Jr.''' is on his [http://www.arlingtoncemetery.net/kinchel.htm grave marker] at [[Arlington National Cemetery]].
However, his first name is sometimes spelled '''Ivan'''.
{{cite web |last=Bryan |first=C. D. B. |date=1979-09-23 |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1979/09/23/books/1979wolfe-right.html |title=The Right Stuff |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=2006-04-02}} (''[[The Right Stuff (book)|The Right Stuff]]'', however, consistently uses '''Iven''').
{{cite web |year=1997 |url=http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/crippen-rl.html |title=Astronaut bio: Robert L. Crippen |publisher=NASA, Johnson Space Center |accessdate=2006-04-02}} (July 2, 1928{{cite web |last=Burns |first=Curtis A. |year=1975 |url=http://www.wpafb.af.mil/museum/afp/kinch.htm |title=Capt. Iven C. Kincheloe Jr. |publisher=National Museum of the United States Air Force |accessdate=2006-04-02 |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20060225004912/http://www.wpafb.af.mil/museum/afp/kinch.htm |archivedate=2006-02-25}} – July 26, 1958{{cite web |url=http://www.af.mil/history/person.asp?dec=&pid=123006465 |title=Captain Iven C. Kincheloe Jr. |publisher=Air Force Link |accessdate=2006-04-02 |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20051025063935/http://www.af.mil/history/person.asp?dec=&pid=123006465 |archivedate=2005-10-25}}), ([[Captain (United States)|Capt]], [[United States Air Force|USAF]]), was an [[United States|American]] [[test pilot]], recipient of the [[Silver Star]] and [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)|Distinguished Flying Cross]], [[aeronautical engineer]], and an [[Flying ace|ace]] in the [[Korean War]]. ==Early life and education== Kincheloe was born July 2, 1928, in [[Detroit, Michigan]] but grew up in [[Cassopolis, Michigan]]. He was the only child of Iven C. Kincheloe Sr. (1894–1966) and Frances Wilder Kincheloe.[http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=2722 Kincheloe's parents], He was interested in aircraft from a very young age. Following his high school graduation in 1945, he attended [[Purdue University]]. He joined the [[Reserve Officers' Training Corps|ROTC]], was a member of [[Sigma Phi Epsilon]]-Indiana Alpha fraternity, and graduated with a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in [[Aeronautical Engineering]] in 1949. In the summer of 1948, the ROTC cadet was able to meet [[Chuck Yeager]] and sit in the cockpit of the [[Bell X-1]]. ==Korean War== After graduating in 1949, Kincheloe received his [[Officer (armed forces)|commission]] in the [[United States Air Force|U.S. Air Force]]. After receiving his [[U.S. Air Force aeronautical rating|pilot wings]] in August 1950, he spent a year as a test pilot flying the [[F-86 Sabre|F-86E]] at [[Edwards Air Force Base]], [[California]] before being promoted to [[first lieutenant]] and transferred to [[Korea]] in September 1951. During the war, he flew [[P-80 Shooting Star|F-80s]] on 30 [[Aerial warfare|combat missions]] and [[F-86 Sabre|F-86s]] on 101 combat missions, downing five [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-15|MiG-15s]] (becoming an [[Flying ace|ace]] and earning the [[Silver Star]]) before returning to the U.S. in May 1952. At this time, he had reached the rank of [[Captain (United States)|captain]]. ==Post-war career== After the war, first he worked as a gunnery instructor at the [[Nellis Air Force Base]], [[Nevada]]. Then, he again became a test pilot, graduating in December 1954 from the [[Empire Test Pilots' School]] at [[Farnborough, Hampshire|Farnborough, England]]. He participated in the testing of the [[Century Series]] of [[fighter aircraft]] ([[F-100 Super Sabre]], [[F-101 Voodoo]], [[F-102 Delta Dagger]], [[F-104 Starfighter]], [[F-105 Thunderchief]], and [[F-106 Delta Dart]]). In the mid-1950s, Kincheloe joined the [[Bell X-2]] program and on September 7, 1956,{{cite book |last=Taylor |first=Michael J.H. |coauthors=Christopher Chant (other chapters) |title=The world's greatest aircraft |year=1999 |publisher=Regency House Publishing Ltd. |location=Hertfordshire |isbn=1-85605-523-X |chapter=The chronology of flight 1940 to [1999-03-25] |quote=The Bell X-2 research aircraft is flown by Capt. Iven C. Kincheloe to an altitude of 126,200 ft (38,466m). |page=388}} flew at more than {{convert|2000|mi/h|km/h|abbr=on}} and to a height of {{convert|126200|ft|m}} (some sources list 126,500), the first flight ever above 100,000 feet. For this he was nicknamed "America's No. 1 Spaceman". The [[Bell X-2|X-2]] program was halted just three weeks later after a fatal crash resulted in the death of [[Mel Apt]] in a flight in which Apt became the first person to exceed Mach 3. Three years later, Kincheloe was selected as one of the first three pilots in the next rocket-powered aircraft program, the [[North American X-15|X-15]], and would have been part of the [[Man In Space Soonest]] project. He was killed in the crash of an [[F-104 Starfighter|F-104]]A at [[Edwards Air Force Base|Edwards AFB]], and was buried with full military honors at [[Arlington National Cemetery]].{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=dgIqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=iCYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7467%2C4383188 |newspaper=Milwaukee Journal |title=Eisenhower asks favor of the 1972-'76 president |agency=Associated Press |date=November 18, 1958 |page=4}} He was only 30 years old and was survived by wife, Dorothy, their young son, Iven, III, and a daughter who would be born two months later, Jeannine.[http://www.nationalaviation.org/kincheloe-jr-iven-carl/ Kincheloe's family], ==Legacy== * In September 1959, [[Kincheloe Air Force Base]] in Michigan's [[Upper Peninsula of Michigan|Upper Peninsula]] was renamed in his honor; the base closed in September 1977. * A monument stands approximately 1-1/2 miles east of his hometown of [[Cassopolis, Michigan]]; it is an angular stone slab twelve feet high bearing a silver model of the X-2 pointed skyward. * Kincheloe Elementary School, part of the nearby Dowagiac Union School District, is named in his honor. * The television program ''[[Hogan's Heroes]]'' featured a character called Staff Sergeant James (a.k.a. Ivan) Kinchloe. * In 1992, he was inducted into the [[Aerospace Walk of Honor]]. * In 2011, he was inducted into the [[National Aviation Hall of Fame]]."[http://www.nationalaviation.org/2011-enshrinement/ 50th Annual Enshrinement Dinner and Ceremony]". ''National Aviation Hall of Fame'' website. Retrieved on 2011-07-23.{{cite news |first=Lou |last=Mumford |format= |title=An Honor Long Overdue |url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/southbendtribune/access/2405321101.html?FMT=ABS |work=[[South Bend Tribune]] |publisher= |date=2011-07-22 |accessdate=2011-07-25}} * The [[Iven C. Kincheloe Award]] is named in his honor. * The Purdue University [[Arnold Air Society]] squadron is named in his honor. ==See also== {{Portal|Biography|United States Air Force}} * [[List of Korean War air aces]] * [[Elmer W. Harris]], fellow Korean squadron pilot ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Iven Carl Kincheloe Jr.}} * [http://www.acepilots.com/korea/kincheloe.html Korean War Aces] * [http://www.nationalmuseum.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=1113 USAF Museum] * [http://www.combatsim.com/memb123/htm/2002/07/flak/ Story about exploits @ CombatSim] * [http://www.southbendtribune.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060907/News01/609070412 "Cassopolis native first man in space"] – ''[[South Bend Tribune]]'', September 7, 2006 * [http://www.southbendtribune.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060924/News01/609240424 "Kincheloe monument restored, rededicated"] – ''[[South Bend Tribune]]'', September 24, 2006 * [http://www.afa.org/magazine/Sept2006/0906aces.pdf Photograph of Kincheloe with other pilots of his squadron wearing red caps and scarves], "Sabres and Aces", ''Air Force Magazine'', September 2006, p. 81. * [http://www.nationalaviation.org/kincheloe-jr-iven-carl/ Iven C. Kincheloe Jr.] at the [[National Aviation Hall of Fame]] * [http://www.astronautix.com/astros/kinheloe.htm Astronautix biography of Iven C. Kincheloe Jr.] * [http://www.arlingtoncemetery.net/kinchel.htm Iven C. Kincheloe Jr.] Photograph of his grave marker at Arlington National Cemetery, with brief biography. * {{Find a Grave|2722|Iven C. Kincheloe Jr.}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kincheloe, Iven}} [[Category:1928 births]] [[Category:1958 deaths]] [[Category:Accidental deaths in California]] [[Category:American Korean War flying aces]] [[Category:American test pilots]] [[Category:American aviators]] [[Category:Aviators from Michigan]] [[Category:American engineers]] [[Category:American aerospace engineers]] [[Category:Aviators killed in aviation accidents or incidents in the United States]] [[Category:American military personnel of the Korean War]] [[Category:Burials at Arlington National Cemetery]] [[Category:Mackay Trophy winners]] [[Category:People from Cass County, Michigan]] [[Category:Purdue University alumni]] [[Category:Recipients of the Silver Star]] [[Category:Recipients of the Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)]] [[Category:United States Air Force officers]] [[Category:Flight altitude record holders]]
